sn22.159:1.2: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
sn22.159:1.3: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”
sn22.159:2.4: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn22.159:2.6: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and liable to fall apart, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn22.159:2.7: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn22.159:2.14: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn22.159:2.16: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and liable to fall apart, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn22.159:2.17: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn22.159:2.20: They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’”
sn22.159:4.5: The Linked Discourses on the aggregates are complete.
